title: Friday, 20th April, 2018

Miss Piggy "Until last night we assumed the weak data flow would not derail a May hike. There were no signs of cold feet at the Bank of England after a hawkish March policy meeting and rate setter Jan Vlieghe arguing for six hikes in the next three years.
Miss Piggy "Then last night Governor Mark Carney suggested delay. In a BBC interview he said the BoE was conscious of “other meetings over the course of the year” when they could hike.
Soundbuy Aye, Shire shenanigans.............
Miss Piggy "As hints go, we think it’s as strong as we get. The data justify delay in our view. We have been sceptical of the need for a May hike. We stick with a May hike for now, waiting to see if other rate setters speak. But the 85% market probability on a May hike looks (much) too high now.

We did the Takeda bid side here yesterday. What followed was .... curious.

BE11:13am

To summarise:

11:13 am

Panel: are you thinking about bidding for Shire?
Allergan: Of course!
Panel: really?
Allergan: no.

Soundbuy A load of Botox then......
BE11:15am

So ...... it sure was curious how that story of a potential counterbidder ended up with Reuters, right? A story that was pretty helpful to the Shire case ........

11:15 am
BE11:15am

.... but seemed less helpful to the Allergan case, as everyone went "how the hell would that work then?" and the shares cratered.

Maverick Who's going to come out of the wood work next Pfizer, Abbvie... Certainly many possibilities.
BE11:16am

Was this Allergan just not understanding how to navigate the Panel? The rules regarding this stuff are much lighter in the US.

Mouselet Good morning miscellaneous, assorted and other auspicious personages
BornCynic The bit of news that got me was that the Brexit bill keeps going up - so predicted lower growth and a large bill for it................
Paper Chase I note Bloomberg piece this morning (Lisa Du, Maiko Takahashi) positing that Takeda needs a Shire to fill its half-empty pipeline and thus Christophe Weber may have the bit between his teeth and isn't giving up. Which I guess doesn't necessarily chime too well with the official line of 'remaining disciplined'.
BE11:18am

Now, I could speculate here about how some folk might believe they can use media coverage to their advantage, but won't. Instead, I'll just catch us up with where we are, with a bid battle looking less rather than more likely.

11:19 am
BE11:19am

Credit Suisse:

BE11:19am

Shire’s rejection of Takeda’s bid likely came as no surprise to Takeda, in that Shire expected that other companies would make counteroffers, and probably now is prepared to reconsider Takeda’s pitch. With Allergan out of the picture, Takeda and Shire say they are continuing discussions regarding a potential offer, and we now see an increased likelihood of the pair reaching an agreement.

BE11:20am

They, like most sellside, expect Takeda to improve the cash portion

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Possible counterbidders? Maybe, I guess.

GBKrona @paperchase - excellent, thanks - do you have the link pls?
Paper Chase Am I allowed to post link @BE?
BE11:22am

Takeda's easy to beat due to limited headroom, of course. Though SocGen says unlikely.

BE11:22am

The third Takeda offer implies a peak pro forma net debt/EBITDA ratio of c.4x. Now the maximum such ratio we’ve witnessed in large cap Pharma M&A was 5x when Shire acquired Baxalta in mid-2016. Hence, simplistically an extra point of leverage would imply that Takeda could raise its cash component by another £9/Shire share. But we suspect that the Shire share price discounts otherwise because of Takeda’s credit rating and/or dividend commitments (NB equity has already accounted for 70% of the increase in Takeda’s bid). Allergan is similarly sized to Takeda and in our view faces not only similar financial constraints but also offers weaker strategic rationale. We acknowledge that other potential suitors have been discussed. But we believe that neither Novartis (Buy) nor AbbVie (Buy) strategically need Shire. We also suspect that Pfizer (Hold) is no longer interested in transformational M&A. We also calculate that the equity which both Celgene and Allergan would have to raise would excessively dilute their consensus EPS estimates. However, we do note that the bid premium remained in the AstraZeneca (Buy) share price for 6-12months after Pfizer formally walked away

11:22 am
BE11:22am

(@Paper Chase: of course.)

Paper Chase Ta. https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-04-20/shire-rebuff-may-not-dim-takeda-s-appetite-for-60-billion-deal
GBKrona thanks @paperchase
Maverick T'you
Paper Chase (Doesn't say much we don't already know, except for a bit more colour around the human angle)
BE11:24am

One under-examined part of this, maybe, is whether certain bidders might be a bit cautious around Shire because of its previous activities.

BE11:24am

This, from 2013, is good: https://www.nytime...icit-disorder.html

11:25 am
BE11:26am

Brian Lutz, a Shire salesman for Adderall XR from 2004 to 2009, said he met with 75 psychiatrists in his Oakland, Calif., territory at least every two weeks — about 30 to 40 times apiece annually — to show them posters and pamphlets that highlighted the medicine’s benefits for grades and behavior.

If a psychiatrist asked about issues like side effects or abuse, Mr. Lutz said, they were played down. He said he was told to acknowledge risks matter-of-factly for legal reasons, but to refer only to the small print in the package insert or offer Shire’s phone number for more information.

“It was never like, ‘This is a serious side effect, you need to watch out for it,’ ” Mr. Lutz recalled. “You wanted to give them more information because we’re talking about kids here, you know? But it was all very positive.”

tangledodyssey Shire seem to have been a takeover target for ever
BE11:28am

Any DD on Shire, I imagine, will involve a little examination of whether there's any potential exposure to legacy legal risks. I'm not suggesting those risks present a serious hurdle, to be clear, but they might be something the bigger pharmas would keep in mind.

BE11:28am

Here's UBS.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

We think it is more likely than not a deal gets done, but who precisely does the deal remains murky. First, Takeda could probably increase the cash component of its offer (e.g., high gearing in the short-term to increase the cash component, and then divestment-based de-leverage). But the deal is a real financial stretch for Takeda, which is likely price sensitive. Second, Allergan declared some interest (accepting it quickly evaporated). Third, other bidders could still emerge. And fourth, we think Shire investors are keen to avoid the regret they might feel if they don't sell and then the stock does badly. Regret avoidance can be a powerful motivator.

BE11:29am

Without a suitable Takeda or Allergan bid, we think Shire gives up around half its gains, settling in the £34-£35 range.

BE11:30am

.... so, not £46.50. Some distance away from it, in fact.

Many investors we spoke to felt the intu deal diluted the best parts of its portfolio, so we now assume the group will respond by concentrating on those best parts, with more net disposals, and rather than putting the proceeds towards an intu acquisition, we assume it focusses on development capex and returns to shareholders.

tadam I am sorry but companies have done DD on Shire. If I remember correctly (I may be mistaken) Shire had agreed to be acquired before. If other companies don't bid on Shire it's because it's not an attractive enough takeover target to overpay for.

TB I thought Wenger would make pic of day...

(@Tadam: "Companies"? Abbvie has pushed the button on a bid. No others. Though I agree that plenty have run the numbers.)

BE11:38am

Investors will continue to reference Klepierre's 635p approach, but without an upward rerating of the whole UK property space (or a return of takeover speculation), we fear this will prove an elusive target against a still challenging market backdrop. Our 600p 2019e target assumes a still wide (29)% discount to our 2019e NAV forecast, equivalent to a 5.2% EPS yield and a ~5% dividend yield; this drives sector-beating upside from current levels, hence our Overweight.

BE11:45am

Enhanced regulatory and pricing uncertainty is unhelpful which we have reflected in a higher (by 0.5-1ppt) cost of equity across the subsector. However, we believe that current motor share prices now more than reflect this. We therefore view the recent sell-off as representing an inexpensive entry opportunity into the UK motor space, which we believe offers greater than 6% dividend yield prospects and sound (greater than 15%) operating margins (on a weighted average basis).

Bluesky21 Can someone just buy Saga's customer base and take out all the costs?
11:45 am
BE11:46am

They like Esure. As, I think, does Peel Hunt. This is CS:

BE11:46am

Despite competitive headwinds Esure has continued to accelerate growth, through its footprint expansion programme, which involves growing into higher risk customer segments. With the customer profiles in the riskier cohorts largely similar to the core (more conservative) book and as Esure continues to depict solid pricing discipline, we are more comfortable with the risks associated with this strategy. Therefore, following the recent c40% share price de-rating over several months, we now envisage greater upside to the shares and see appeal in 8% total (including specials) dividend yield prospects. We therefore upgrade the shares to Outperform (from Neutral).

A better grasp of the issues within the broking business and a sound strategy to tackle them are however encouraging. We also believe that developments on the search for a new CFO and the recent appointment of a new (insurance focused) Chairman will likely be a significant driver of sentiment over the course of the year.

BE11:54am

The weakness in the share price has prompted analysts at Deutsche Bank to speculate that CRH might want to look at a partial or full listing of the US business in New York to unlock value, as the group’s stock, mainly traded in London and Dublin, trades at a discount to US peers.

“In my 20 years in CRH we’ve certainly looked at it a number of times, but every time we’ve looked at it it’s never made sense,” said Manifold. “But we keep an open mind, and it’s something we keep under review with our advisers.”

When asked if he may take advantage of a perceived undervaluation of the group’s stock and launch a share buyback programme, the CEO said: “Again it’s something we keep under careful review. We’ve done it in the past, and I suspect we’ll do it again at some stage.”

tangledodyssey Straight out of the Manual of Directorspeakwaffle
11:56 am
BE11:57am

While reviewed from time to time, the prospect of a part-listing of the US business appears remote at present. The CEO states that, while the group has looked at it many times over the past 20 years, “it has never made sense”. That type of a spin-off would impact on savings the group achieves from centrally procuring goods and services. Procurement savings, in particular, appear significant with about $14bn of products and services bought in the US alone where the group is saving c.2.5-3%. Best practice savings also appear significant with the group’s European cement businesses, helping drive synergies from the Ash Grove acquisition.

BE11:57am

And UBS.

FATDAZ is too late to seek out roof terrace
BE11:58am

The CEO points out that a larger global group has material procurement benefits and has the ability to share knowledge. For example, the entry into the US cement market with the acquisition of Ash Grove will draw heavily on the expertise of running cement businesses in the US. Additionally, we think there is also some benefit in geographic diversification in cyclical businesses, although arguably investors can achieve this through different means. The obvious pro of splitting would likely be an overall higher valuation (we recently published our view of an SOP valuation of £33). So, while CRH is keeping an "open mind" about a potential listing of the US, we think it is unlikely in the short term.

11:58 am
BE11:58am

Buy-back is perhaps more realistic to expect
At the stage of the FY17 results, CRH said it thought it could create more value through allocating capital into M&A than repurchasing own shares. It appears the thinking on this has somewhat moved on, which may mean a buy-back could potentially be more seriously considered.
